name: Reykholt
description: Reykholt is a historic settlement in Borgarfjörður, West Iceland, renowned as the medieval home of Snorri Sturluson (1179-1241), Iceland's most influential historical figure and one of the most important writers of medieval Scandinavia. Snorri settled in Reykholt in 1206 and from this remote cultural center wove a dense network of power and influence extending across Iceland and all the way to the Norwegian royal court. A man of extraordinary talents, Snorri served simultaneously as lawspeaker at the Alþingi (Iceland's parliament), powerful chieftain, prolific writer, and accomplished skaldic poet. At Reykholt, he authored two of medieval literature's most important works: the Prose Edda, an invaluable guide to Norse mythology and poetic techniques that preserved pagan myths that would otherwise have been lost to Christianity's spread, and Heimskringla, a comprehensive saga chronicling the lives of Norwegian kings from legendary times through the 12th century. These literary masterpieces, composed in Old Norse, remain fundamental sources for understanding Viking Age culture, Norse mythology, and medieval Scandinavian history. Snorri's life ended violently at Reykholt on September 23, 1241, when he was assassinated in his cellar on orders from the Norwegian king Hákon Hákonarson, who had grown suspicious of Snorri's political maneuvering. The site preserves Snorralaug, a circular geothermal pool measuring approximately 4 meters in diameter that Snorri used for bathing in the 13th century.
